IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: THE MINNESOTA ZOO FOUNDATION'S PRIMARY PURPOSE IS TO RAISE FUNDS FOR THE MINNESOTA ZOO.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The Minnesota Zoo Foundation's primary purpose is to raise funds for the Minnesota Zoological Garden.
IRS990.Description: Provided grants to the Minnesota Zoological Garden to support the Zoo's conservation and education mission.

Activity2.Description: Provided grants to support Zoo related conservation and education activities around the world.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Foundation's endowment consists of permanently restricted and temporarily restricted funds established for the following purposes: Permanently restricted funds are donor restricted to be held in perpetuity, with the income and related investment gains to be used for donor restricted zoo programs or operations. Temporarily restricted funds are the accumulation of earnings from the permanently restricted endowment that have not been appropriated for expenditure, with the income and related investment gains to be used for any mission related program.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Foundation is a tax-exempt organization under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and Minnesota Statute 290.05. It has been classified as an organization that is not a private foundation under the Internal Revenue Code and charitable contributions by donors are tax deductible. However, any unrelated business income may be subject to taxation. In accordance with the accounting standard on Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes, the Foundation addressed the determination of whether tax benefits claimed on a tax return should be recorded in the financial statements. Under this guidance, the Foundation may recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by taxing authorities, based on the technical merit of the position. Examples of tax positions include the tax-exempt status of the Foundation and various positions related to the potential sources of unrelated business taxable income. There were no significant unrecognized tax benefits or recorded liabilities during fiscal year 2010. Open tax years subject to examination by U.S. and state taxing authorities are for the years 2007 to 2009, which statutes expire in 2010 to 2012, respectively.
Change in Beneficial Interest in Trust: 60193. Direct Expenses From Special Events: 177390. Direct Benefit: -66180.
Change in Beneficial Interest in Trust: 60193.
Direct Expenses from Special Events : -177390. Direct Benefit: 66180.

Form990ScheduleFPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants Outside the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleFPartIV.Explanation: Schedule F, Part I, Line 2: Once the grant has been approved, the funds are used at the discretion of the grantee.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: The Minnesota Zoo Foundation does not require any follow-up from grant recipients.

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.DescriptionOfTransaction: Ross Kramer is a partner in the firm Messerli and Kramer. Messerli and Kramer provides advocacy services to the Minnesota Zoo Foundation. The Minnesota Zoo Foundation paid $60,000 to Messerli and Kramer for these services. The transaction was conducted in the normal course of business.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 1
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The committee is comprised of the past chair, chair, vice chair, treasurer and secretary of the board of trustees, co-chair of the governance committee, and the chair of the corporate relations committee. The president is the only non-voting member. Primary purpose is to exercise powers which arise between regularly scheduled board meetings or when it is not practical or feasible for the Board to meet. All actions taken by the executive committee are reported and ratified at a regular meeting of the board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Board member Charlene Jundt and Board member Peter Maritz: family relationship.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The finance committee, the executive committee and the rest of the board each review and approve the draft of the 990 before it is filed.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The foundation requires each trustee to review this policy annually, disclose any possible personal, familial, or business relationships that reasonably could give rise to a conflict and acknowledge, by his or her signature, compliance with the letter and spirit of this policy. Trustees or senior staff who have declared or been found to have a conflict of interest shall refrain from participating in the consideration of proposed transactions that give rise to the conflict, unless for special reasons information or interpretation from the person with the conflict is specifically requested by the board or administration. Persons with conflicts shall not vote or be present at the time of the vote on the matter giving rise to the conflict.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Review of comparable salary data from Minnesota Council of Nonprofits. The board chair and executive committee approves the executive director's compensation. For all other employees, the Executive Director reviews and approves compensation based off of comparable data.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The oversight and selection process has not changed from prior year.
